Dear Jason Lheureux:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the violations
identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The corrective action plan is
due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact me. In
any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an acceptable
corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any questions. In
the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone immediately, please contact
the area manager Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.
Sincerely,
Shannon (Shay) Mavis
Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code CCI Rule 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions
Title & (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Section policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
Description intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(iv)Verbal abuse including the use of derogatory or
discriminatory language including negative references to a youth’s
background or appearance or mental state. Yelling, threats,
ridicule, or humiliation are strictly prohibited.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth ran away to the hospital due to suicidal ideation and verbal
mistreatment by staff. Youth was fearful of returning to the facility.
When youth did return, the facility appeared dark. When youth
asked to change their clothes upon returning, the staff member
was verbally inappropriate, hostile, loud, and aggressive.
Investigation INTERVIEWS:
Emergency Medical Technician (EMT) 1 was interviewed via
phone on 6/10/24. EMT 1 reported she and EMT 2 were called to
the hospital to take Youth A back to the facility on 6/9/24. EMT 1
reported Youth A told hospital staff she was scared to go back to
the facility. However, Youth A was sweet, calm, and cooperative,
and got onto the stretcher fine with no objection. EMT 1 reported
in the ambulance, Youth A reported she wasn’t safe at the facility,
there was a lot of verbal abuse going on and “they” were going to
hurt her. EMT 1 reported Youth A did not specify whether the
verbal abuse was by youth or staff and did not provide any
examples. Youth A also did not specify whether she was afraid of
being harmed by youth or staff. EMT 1 reported she offered to talk
to someone about what Youth A was experiencing at the facility,
but Youth A got very wide-eyed and said, “No, no, no, don’t do
that. It’ll make it worse”. EMT 1 reported Youth A had a bruise on
2

her forearm but didn’t want to elaborate on how she received the
bruise. EMT 1 reported Youth A was still in the hospital gown
when she arrived back at the facility. EMT 1 reported a male staff
and a female staff escorted EMT 1, EMT 2, and Youth A on the
stretcher to the facility. EMT 1 reported there was a Caucasian
female staff with dark hair and glasses who was on the unit when
they arrived. EMT 1 reported Youth A asked the female staff if she
could go to her room and change out of her hospital gown, but the
female staff yelled at Youth A and said, “No you can’t go back to
your room. You made the choices you did yesterday, so this is
your fault why you can’t go back to your room”. EMT 1 reported
the response seemed very uncalled for and inappropriate.
EMT 2 was interviewed via phone on 6/10/24. EMT 2 reported
when she and EMT 1 arrived at the hospital to transport Youth A
back to the facility, Youth A began freaking out and acting scared.
EMT 2 reported Youth A said she was dizzy, lightheaded, was
prediabetic, and didn’t know why she was being sent back to the
facility when it wasn’t safe there. EMT 2 reported Youth A had a
bruise on her forearm, but hospital staff and Youth A did not tell
EMT 1 or EMT 2 where the bruise came from. Youth A told EMT 2
she didn’t want to go back to the facility because “they” are
verbally abusive, but Youth A did not specify whether it was youth
or staff. Youth A did not provide any names for youth or staff who
were verbally abusive towards her. EMT 2 reported when they
arrived at the residence hall, there was a female staff behind the
reception desk. EMT 2 reported Youth A asked the female staff if
she could go to her room to get changed. EMT 2 reported the
female staff was aggressive and forceful in her response and said
“No, you can’t go back there. You know why you can’t go to your
room”. EMT 2 reported Youth A was very polite in her interactions,
but the female staff’s reaction was loud, aggressive, unnecessary,
and made EMT 2 very uncomfortable.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on 6/11/24.
Youth A reported all staff except Staff 3, Staff 4, Staff 5, Staff 6,
and Staff 7 are verbally abusive, but could not provide any
examples of verbal abuse she has witnessed or been victim of.
Youth A reported staff can be threatening by saying “Alright, y’all
want to act like this. I got something for y’all” and proceed to shut
down the program. Youth A could not name a specific staff
member who has said that and could not name any other ways
any staff have been threatening. Youth A reported Supervisor 2 is
the staff who gets mad when youth ask to have doors opened, or
request items. Youth A reported Supervisor 2 frequently yells at
them and shows she’s irritated. Youth A reported on 6/9/24, she
3

arrived on the unit after being brought back from the hospital, and
Staff 4 was fine, but Supervisor 2 was not. Youth A reported she
asked Supervisor 2 if she could go to her bedroom to get
changed, and Supervisor 2 told her no. Youth A reported
Supervisor 2 did not yell at her or speak to her inappropriately.
Youth A reported she was irritated Supervisor 2 wouldn’t let her
get clothes out of her room, but Supervisor 2 and Therapist talked
to her and explained why, so she understood even though she
wasn’t happy about it. Youth A reported she when she told EMT 1
and EMT 2 about being fearful of someone physically harming
her, she was speaking about Youth C because they weren’t on
good terms prior to Youth A going to the hospital. Youth A
reported no staff at the facility have physically harmed her. Youth
A reported the bruising on her forearm/wrist came from her falling
when she was running through the woods on 6/8/24 when she
went AWOL. Youth A reported Staff 1 cusses at youth sometimes
and has told her she needs to “get her shit together”. Youth A
reported Staff 1 is very stern, and he becomes angry very quickly,
which he demonstrates by being loud. Youth A reported one time
Staff 1 told a youth (couldn’t remember who), “I’m so sick of your
fucking bullshit”. Youth A reported when Staff 1 reacts in those
ways or becomes loud, it scares her.
Youth B and Youth D were interviewed separately face to face
at the facility on 6/20/24. Youth B and Youth D reported they do
not have any concerns with staff’s interactions with youth. Youth B
and Youth D reported no staff yell, scream, cuss, or threaten
youth.
Youth C was interviewed face to face at the facility on 6/20/24.
Youth C reported there are certain staff, such as Supervisor 2,
who will match energies of the youth they are interacting with.
Youth C reported if she yells at Supervisor 2, then Supervisor 2
might raise her voice or yell back. Youth C reported the only times
she has heard any staff yell is when they’re trying to get a youth’s
attention during an escalated situation, but not as a sign of
disrespect or being verbally abusive. Youth C reported she has
never heard any staff yell, scream, cuss, or threaten any youth
except Staff 1. Youth C reported one time around Mother’s Day
2024, Staff 1 was asked to stay and work a double shift, and she
heard him say “this is fucking irritating”, but he wasn’t cussing at a
youth. Youth C reported another time she was escalated, and
Staff 1 said, “If this was out in the real world, I would put my hands
on you”. Youth C reported recently she was talking to another
youth about her history and expressed her frustration about being
in the foster care system since she was 11 years old without a
4

family wanting to adopt her. Youth C reported Supervisor 2 was
listening to the conversation and scoffed when Youth C mentioned
a family. Youth C reported she became frustrated and asked
Supervisor 2 to stop because it was bothering her. Youth C
reported Supervisor 2 said “well that’s why you’re here, because
no family wants you”.
Chief Administrator (CA) was interviewed face to face at the
facility on 6/11/24. CA reported the female staff who was present
on the unit on 6/9/24 and matches EMT 1’s description was
Supervisor 2. CA reported Supervisor 2’s tone of voice and pace
can come off wrong to youth and staff, so it is a continued work in
progress being addressed with her.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
6/11/24. Supervisor 1 reported Youth A has a low IQ and has
PTSD, which frequently manifest in misrepresentation of facts and
nuances of social interactions with others. Supervisor 1 reported
Youth A perceives people not doing what she wants or putting
boundaries up as “abuse” or “disrespect”. Supervisor 1 reported
whenever Youth A has brought him a concern about staff, he has
followed up on the concerns by reviewing paperwork, conducting
internal investigations, or sending the information to the recipient’s
rights office for investigation. Supervisor 1 reported Youth A has
had specific complaints about every staff who works at the facility
at one time or another. Supervisor 1 reported Youth A has
complained Supervisor 2 is too loud, speaks too quickly, or
speaks over her. Supervisor 1 reported Youth A has never
complained any staff have been verbally abusive towards her.
Supervisor 1 reported Youth A has never complained about Staff
1 cussing at her, and Youth C has never complained about Staff 1
threatening her. Supervisor 1 reported no staff, including Staff 1,
have ever been mandated for a shift, so he’s not sure where
Youth C received her information for her complaint about Staff 1
cussing.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 6/20/24.
Staff 1 reported he has never heard any staff yell, scream, cuss,
or threaten any youth. Staff 1 reported he hasn’t seen Supervisor
2 do any of those things either, but sometimes she gets into power
struggles with youth, which he doesn’t feel are always necessary.
Staff 1 reported his voice is deep and loud, but he doesn’t ever
raise his voice or yell at youth. Staff 1 reported he is a tall and
stocky male, and knows he has to be very self-aware in his
interactions with others, especially female youth. Staff 1 reported
he knows his voice tends to carry, so when he is speaking directly
5

to a youth, he provides reassurances such as “I’m not yelling” or
“I’m not upset”, to ensure his intentions are understood. Staff 1
reported cussing is not in his verbiage, and he has never said the
statements Youth A or Youth C reported. Staff 1 reported when he
is speaking to the youth, he is respectful, even to the point of
saying “yes ma’am” or “no ma’am”. Staff 1 reported he has never
worked a double shift or been forced to stay after his shift, so he
isn’t sure what situation Youth C is referring to. Staff 1 reported he
tries to teach the youth life lessons, and sometimes he provides
real life examples of consequences for behaviors to prepare them
for life outside of the facility. Staff 1 reported youth are quick to
become physically or verbally assaultive with each other or staff,
so he might say “if you were to put hands on someone outside of
the facility, there could be consequences (i.e. physical fight,
getting shot, etc.), and staff won’t be there to redirect you, so you
have to change your behaviors”. Staff 1 reported he is always
reminding the youth their goal is to get out of the facility, and they
need to grow so they’re prepared for the real world. Staff 1
reported he has never threatened to put his own hands on the
youth or threatened to use physical violence against any of the
youth.
Staff 4 was interviewed via phone on 7/17/24. Staff 4 reported
she was present on 6/9/24 when EMT 1 and EMT 2 brought Youth
A back to the facility. Staff 4 reported when Youth A returned,
Youth A asked Supervisor 2 if she could go into her room and get
changed. Staff 4 reported Supervisor 2 let Youth A know she was
moved to a stripped room for suicide precautions, so she could
not go into her room. Staff 4 reported when Supervisor 2
responded, she wasn’t loud, aggressive, or inappropriate. Staff 4
reported Supervisor 2 and Youth A went down a bedroom hallway
to have a private conversation, but she didn’t hear what they were
saying. Staff 4 reported Youth A and Supervisor 2’s interactions
typically tend to be louder in nature, but she didn’t hear an
escalated or loud conversation between them in the hallway. Staff
4 reported Youth A and Supervisor 2 have a unique relationship,
which ends up being more like a mother-daughter relationship.
Staff 4 reported they have disagreements and arguments, but
Youth A gets over them quickly. Staff 4 reported she has never
seen or heard any staff scream, threaten, yell at, or cuss at Youth
A.
Staff 5 was interviewed via phone on 7/17/24. Staff 5 reported
she has never seen or heard any staff threaten, cuss, yell,
scream, degrade, or humiliate any youth.
6

Staff 6 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 6/20/24.
Staff 6 reported he has never threatened, yelled, cussed at, or
screamed at any youth at the facility, and he hasn’t heard any
other staff do it either. Staff 6 reported he has heard some staff
raise their voices when youth are escalated, but it’s in a direct and
firm tone rather than in an inappropriate way.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
6/20/24. Supervisor 2 reported on 6/9/24, Youth A was brought
back to the facility on a stretcher, and immediately demanded to
go into her room. Supervisor 2 reported she informed Youth A she
was in a stripped room in the opposite hallway for the time being,
and asked Youth A to have a private conversation in the hallway.
When they were in the hallway, Supervisor 2 called Therapist and
they explained to Youth A she was in a stripped room due to
suicide precautions. Supervisor 2 reported the phone call went
well, and afterwards Supervisor 2 grabbed Youth A clothes to
change into. Supervisor 2 reported when she brought Youth A the
clothes, she asked Youth A if she picked an alright outfit, but
Youth A didn’t respond. Supervisor 2 reported Youth A called her
dad a couple times after that, and then Supervisor 2’s shift was
over. Supervisor 2 reported she was direct and stern with Youth A
when they were having a conversation, but never yelled at her and
didn’t feel she was inappropriate in her interactions. Supervisor 2
reported sometimes staff will raise their voices to get youths’
attention, but she has never heard staff threaten, yell, scream or
cuss at any youth.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• Social Work Contact dated 6/9/24 entered by Centralized
Intake noting Nurse oversaw Youth A and there was no
bruising on her arm resembling a handprint. Youth A stated
she did not want to return to the facility, but no reason was
provided.
• Email from Staff 4 dated 6/9/24 stating Youth A is on high-
risk precautions until further notice due to AWOL. She
cannot go into her room or have any items from her room.
• Shift Log dated 6/9/24 notes Youth A was placed on high-
risk status by therapist, which means she is in a stripped
room, and no access to her bedroom is allowed until
bedtime.
• Suicide Precautions Table notes high risk status could
include a youth not being allowed to access their room
7

and/or belongings to reduce risk. Notes youth must remain
in milieu and not be allowed in their room during waking
hours.
• Behavior Management Procedures – Prohibited
Techniques Policy states use of profanity or sarcasm
against a youth is morally unacceptable and
counterproductive to treatment. It also states denial of
clothing is prohibited.
• Code of Conduct policy states every youth must be treated
with dignity and respect, which includes meeting the
highest professional, ethical, and legal standards. Displays
of hostility, aggressive/passive behaviors, demeaning a
youth, or obscene language are not acceptable.
• Supervisor 2 does not have any disciplinary actions in her
employee file. Supervisor 2 completed Decreasing
Behaviors training on 11/30/22 and 8/23/23. She completed
Maintaining Client Dignity Through the Behavior Change
Process on 11/30/22 and 9/6/23. She completed Ensuring
Client Dignity Through the Behavior Change Process on
4/3/24. She completed Ethics and Professionalism training
on 11/30/22, 9/1/23, and 4/8/24.
• Staff 1 has six disciplinary actions in his employee file, all
unrelated to this investigation. Staff 1 completed
Maintaining Professional Boundaries training on 9/23/22.
He completed Client Engagement training on 10/13/22. He
completed a team training on Behavior Plan review on
5/25/23.
Analysis The facility was not found in violation as per interviews conducted
and documentation reviewed, there is not enough information to
support staff have been verbally abusive towards youth.
Despite EMT 1 and EMT 2 expressing concerns regarding the
interaction between Youth A and Supervisor 2 on 6/9/24, Youth A,
Supervisor 2 and Staff 4 did not express the same concerns.
Youth A expressed multiple staff are verbally abusive and make
threats towards her, however, she was unable to provide specific
examples about specific staff except Staff 1. Youth A expressed
concerns with Staff 1 cussing at her, but could not provide any
witnesses to the incidents, did not tell anyone about the incidents
previously and Staff 1 denies the incidents occurred.
8

Youth C reported Staff 1 cussed in front of her once because he
was mandated to stay for a double shift, but Staff 1 and
Supervisor 1 reported Staff 1 has never been mandated to stay
past his shift or work a double shift. Youth C also stated Staff 1
said he would put his hands on her if they were outside of the
facility because of her behavior; however, based on Staff 1’s
explanation of lessons he teaches the youth, it is believed this
interaction was misinterpreted.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code CCI Rule 400.4109 Program Statement
Title & (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Section statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
Description (c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation On multiple occasions, Staff 2 used a vape in her car while
transporting Youth A.
Investigation INTERVIEWS:
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on 6/11/24.
Youth A reported a few weeks prior, Staff 2 smoked vapes in the
car when she was transporting Youth A. Youth A reported it’s
happened on more than one occasion but couldn’t provide exact
dates. Youth A reported she reported the information to
Supervisor 1. Youth A reported no other youth or staff were
present when Staff 2 smoked vapes.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
6/11/24. Supervisor 1 reported Staff 2 was terminated on 6/3/24
for many reasons, but one reason was because of Youth A’s
complaint regarding Staff 2 using a vape while transporting her.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
6/20/24. Supervisor 2 reported Youth A reported the vape issue
regarding Staff 2 to her approximately 3-4 weeks prior and
Supervisor 2 notified Supervisor 1 about the concern.
Attempts were made on 7/8/24 and 7/16/24 to conduct a
phone interview with Staff 2. Staff 2’s phone number was not in
service.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
9

• Substance Use Policy states all employees are prohibited
from smoking inside any owned or leased building space or
parking lots (including in a vehicle) of the agency. Smoking
includes use of vaping.
• Staff 2 has one disciplinary record in her employee file,
which was a termination letter (dated 6/3/24) due to her
failing to pass the probationary period. Staff 2 received
training on the substance use policy during orientation in
February 2024.
Analysis The facility is found in violation as per interviews conducted and
documents reviewed, there is information to support Staff 2
smoked vapes when transporting Youth A on at least one or more
occasions.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
SI #2024C0001001SI dated 1/9/24; CAP approved 1/22/24
SI #2024C0001102SI dated 2/21/24; CAP approved 3/13/24
Rule Code CCI Rule 400.4127 Staff to resident ratio
Title & (1) The licensee shall develop and adhere to a written staff-to-child
Section ratio formula for direct care workers. If a child caring institution is
Description contracted by the department to care for youth, the facility will
follow its contracted ratio.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation On multiple occasions, staff have been out of ratio.
Investigation INTERVIEWS:
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on 6/11/24.
Youth A reported there are a lot of days where the facility has
been out of ratio, which occurred most recently on 6/9/24. Youth A
reported on 6/9/24, Staff 4 worked alone with 4 youth on the unit
from approximately 2:30PM-5:00PM. Youth A reported within the
last two weeks, there was a time Staff 5 was left with three youth
during the day despite the ratio being 1:2 during the day. Youth A
reported there are other times staff have been out of ratio as well
but couldn’t remember specific days or circumstances.
Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility on 6/20/24.
Youth B reported there have been times when there aren’t enough
staff on shift, but she could not provide any dates, examples, or
situations when it occurred.
Youth C was interviewed face to face at the facility on 6/20/24.
Youth C reported if there are not enough staff on shift, they call
on-call or have another staff from another unit come over to work.
10

Youth C could not provide any examples for when the facility was
out of ratio.
Youth D was interviewed face to face at the facility on 6/20/24.
Youth D reported she has only been at the facility for a month and
could not think of any situations when there weren’t enough staff
on shift.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 6/20/24.
Staff 1 reported there have been quite a few times where staff
have called in, and their shift has not been filled quickly (i.e.
waiting for the next scheduled person to come in), or at all. Staff 1
reported the ratio is supposed to be 1 staff to 2 youth during the
day, but sometimes they are left with 2 staff members for 5 youth.
Staff 1 reported although he doesn’t work weekends, he knows
there have been struggles to find staff to work weekends to
maintain ratio.
Staff 4 was interviewed via phone on 7/17/24. Staff 4 reported
within the last few months, she has been at the facility working out
of ratio at least three times but could not provide specific dates.
Staff 4 reported typically the ratio issues occur overnight, and on
the weekends. Staff 4 reported she works every other weekend,
and there have been times she has been working 2nd or 3rd shift
with only one other staff even though there are 5 youth on the unit.
Staff 4 reported she has brought up this concern to Staff 7 as well
as Supervisor 1. Staff 4 reported since new staff have been hired
recently, they haven’t been out of ratio. Staff 4 reported on 6/9/24,
they were within ratio because Staff 8 filled in from 3:00-5:00PM
until the next staff was scheduled to work.
Staff 5 was interviewed via phone on 7/17/24. Staff 5 reported
during 1st shift, there have been a couple issues with them being
out of ratio, but it is very rare. Staff 5 reported anytime it happens,
everyone is all hands-on deck trying to get someone to fill in for
the shift or have someone from another license on campus work
on the unit. Staff 5 reported 2nd or 3rd shift have been the biggest
struggle to fill because the ratio is 1 staff member to 2 youth
during waking hours and 1 staff to 4 youth during sleeping hours.
Staff 5 reported there are 5 youth on the unit. Staff 5 reported
there have been a few situations over the last few months where
she was working 2nd shift by herself and was waiting for the 3rd
shift staff to come in so they would be within ratio again. Staff 5
reported if they are out of ratio, it is not typically for more than 1-2
hours. Staff 5 reported the issue is scheduled to be discussed
during team meeting on 7/18/24. Staff 5 reported she doesn’t feel
11

like prior to now the ratio concerns have been fully discussed and
isn’t sure if all staff are aware of their requirements regarding ratio
(i.e. two staff need to be on shift at night since there are five
youth).
Supervisor 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
6/20/24. Supervisor 2 reported if staff call into their shift, an on-call
staff will fill in. Supervisor 2 reported she wasn’t aware of any ratio
issues on 6/9/24, and no one called her to come back to the
facility to fill in.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• VanderArk Program Statement states daytime staffing ratio
is 1:2 and nighttime staffing ratio is 1:4.
• Staff schedules from 3/31/24-7/6/24 for 1st, 2nd, and 3rd
shifts were reviewed. However, the schedules did not
confirm specific dates the facility was out of ratio.
Analysis The facility is found in violation as per interviews conducted the
facility has been out of ratio on at least one or more occasions
over the last few months.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4130 Privacy and confidentiality.
Section (1) An institution shall assure resident and parent privacy and
Description confidentiality and shall protect residents from exploitation.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Staff 2 did not maintain Youth A's privacy and confidentiality.
Investigation INTERVIEWS:
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on 6/11/24.
Youth A reported one time when Staff 2 was transporting her,
Staff 2 was on Facetime with Staff 2’s mother and introduced
Youth A to her. Youth A reported another time, Staff 2 was waiting
outside of the facility with Youth A because Staff 2’s parents were
bringing her food while she was working. Youth A reported Staff 2
introduced Youth A to both of her parents by name. Youth A
reported no other youth or staff were around when these incidents
occurred.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
6/11/24. Supervisor 1 reported he had no knowledge of Staff 2
introducing Youth A to Staff 2’s parent(s) during a Facetime call or
in person at the facility.
12

Attempts were made on 7/8/24 and 7/16/24 to conduct a
phone interview with Staff 2, but Staff 2’s phone number was
not in service.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• Code of Conduct policy states the privacy of each youth
must be respected, and youth information must be
communicated only for the purpose of benefit to the youth
or their protection.
• Confidentiality and Release of Client Information Policy
states all staff must sign a statement confirming their
responsibility to maintaining client confidentiality. All staff
must avoid using youth names when in public (i.e.
presence of persons who are not agency staff, students, or
volunteers).
• Staff 2 has one disciplinary record in her employee file,
which was a termination letter (dated 6/3/24) due to her
failing to pass the probationary period. Staff 2 received
training on the code of conduct and privacy/confidentiality
policies during orientation in February 2024.
Analysis The facility is found in violation as per interviews conducted Staff 2
violated Youth A’s confidentiality by introducing her to Staff 2’s
parents.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code CCI Rule 400.4148 Personal hygiene
Title & (1) An institution shall assure that each resident maintains or
Section receives personal care, hygiene, and grooming appropriate to the
Description resident’s age, sex, race, cultural background, and health needs.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation On one occasion, a staff failed to provide for Youth A's personal
hygiene needs.
Investigation INTERVIEWS:
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on 6/11/24.
Youth A reported one time (didn’t know exactly when) she was on
her monthly menstrual cycle and asked a staff (didn’t remember
